content: A Cloud Across the Sun
In the twelfth year, on the first day of the twelfth month, ’s Message came to me: “Son of man, sing a funeral lament over Pharaoh king of Egypt. Tell him:
“‘You think you’re a young lion
You’re more like a dragon in the ocean,
“‘, the Master, says:
“‘I’m going to throw my net over you
I’ll dump you on the ground
And bring in all the crows and vultures
I’ll invite wild animals from all over the world
I’ll scatter hunks of your meat in the mountains
The country, right up to the mountains,
When I blot you out,
I’ll throw a cloud across the sun
I’ll turn out every light in the sky above you
I’ll shake up everyone worldwide
I’ll shock people with you.
I’ll shake my sword
On the day you crash, they’ll tremble,
To Lay Your Pride Low
“‘, the Master, says:
“‘The sword of the king of Babylon
I’ll use the swords of champions
Use the most brutal of nations
I’ll destroy all their livestock
Neither human foot nor animal hoof
I’ll clear their springs and streams,
When I turn Egypt back to the wild
When I strike dead all who live there,
In the twelfth year, on the fifteenth day of the first month, ’s Message came to me:
“Son of man, lament over Egypt’s pompous ways.
Dispatch Egypt
To the underworld,
Say, ‘You think you’re so high and mighty?

“She’ll be dumped in with those killed in battle. The sword is bared. Drag her off in all her proud pomp! All the big men and their helpers down among the dead and buried will greet them: ‘Welcome to the grave of the heathen! Join the ranks of the victims of war!’

“Assyria is there and its congregation, the whole nation a cemetery. Their graves are in the deepest part of the underworld, a congregation of graves, all killed in battle, these people who terrorized the land of the living.

“Elam is there in all her pride, a cemetery—all killed in battle, dumped in her heathen grave with the dead and buried, these people who terrorized the land of the living. They carry their shame with them, along with the others in the grave. They turned Elam into a resort for the pompous dead, landscaped with heathen graves, slaughtered in battle. They once terrorized the land of the living. Now they carry their shame down with the others in deep earth. They’re in the section set aside for the slain in battle.

“Meshech-tubal is there in all her pride, a cemetery in uncircumcised ground, dumped in with those slaughtered in battle—just deserts for terrorizing the land of the living. Now they carry their shame down with the others in deep earth. They’re in the section set aside for the slain. They’re segregated from the heroes, the old-time giants who entered the grave in full battle dress, their swords placed under their heads and their shields covering their bones, those heroes who spread terror through the land of the living.
“And you, Egypt, will be dumped in a heathen grave, along with all the rest, in the section set aside for the slain.
“Edom is there, with her kings and princes. In spite of her vaunted greatness, she is dumped in a heathen grave with the others headed for the grave.

“The princes of the north are there, the whole lot of them, and all the Sidonians who carry their shame to their graves—all that terror they spread with their brute power!—dumped in unhallowed ground with those killed in battle, carrying their shame with the others headed for deep earth.
“Pharaoh will see them all and, pompous old goat that he is, take comfort in the company he’ll keep—Pharaoh and his slaughtered army. Decree of , the Master.
“I used him to spread terror in the land of the living and now I’m dumping him in heathen ground with those killed by the sword—Pharaoh and all his pomp. Decree of , the Master.”
